(I think it was his way of saying that way my insurance would have to pay for the extra night without argument).

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 03:55AM cateyz2 wrote: Another suggestion I would like to add after reading your post JMFRANKEL is that Ive previously had nausea problems with surgery and my surgeon also gave me a prescription at my pre=op for a anti-nausea patch that I put on behind my ear the day before surgery and anesthesiologist also put some in my IV and it worked beautifully. I didn't take the patch off until after I got discharged
Posts.Title: November 2013 surgeries mimi32 MCbeach

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2013 08:32AM - edited Nov 11, 2013 08:33AM by cateyz2 I slept in the recliner for quite a few weeks with pillows around me. Funny story is early on I did try to sleep in the bed, but couldn't get out in the morning thank goodness my husband hadn't left for work yet and helped me get up. Another funny one was about a 2 weeks after BMX I thought I was ready to drive. I figured I was going to get out of the house for a bit and visit my girlfriend you lives a few miles away. So Igot in my jeep and backed out of the garage but then realized I just didn't have the strength and quick response needed to turn the wheel fast and pulled back into the garage albeit quite crooked. When my son got home he asked who the he** drove my jeep as it was parked pretty much in the middle LOL
Posts.Title: November 2013 surgeries mimi32 MCbeach

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2013 03:26PM cateyz2 wrote: Raynaj Not sure yet what cup size yet I know there is some swelling and cant take my bandages off til Friday. you also mentioned the pain with the dye and when I had my bmx the nurse said that the hospital protocol was to put lidocane in the tip of the syringe so it numbs before the dye gets in there so didn't have the pain. Also with regards to driving yes it was at least three weeks before I drove. Funny story at about 2 weeks I thought I could do it. Backed out of the garage and when I went to turn the wheel it hurt so I pulled right back in the garage. When my son got home from work he asked who the heck was driving my jeep and parked it cockeyed. LOL and said sheepishly that it was me and he proceeded to scold me for driving to early
Posts.Title: November 2013 surgeries mimi32 MCbeach

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2013 05:20PM cateyz2 wrote: JMFrankel- I was off 8 weeks from work, BS said I could go back at 6wks but offered me 2 more for FMLA to be sure I was ready and went for PT and I jumped on the chance. I am a city mail carrier so I life a lot of weight. Some of the trays easily way 50lbs , and parcels that's another story especially this time of year LOL. As far as the drains go, take things slow. The more you move around/use your arms the more fluid you will have. My PS after BMX told me to just keep wearing the stretchy camisoles as they aided in keeping the swelling down. To all of you recent MX sisters, here's to a speedy recovery for all of you with NO complications!!! Hugs

So when I find out what my PS suggests I will let you gals know.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 05:53PM cateyz2 wrote: To all of you ladies having MX this month, just sending you all well wishes from I had mine back in May and will be having my exchange on the 26th. to be quite honest I think the worst of the whole thing is the anxiety of the unknown, as pain meds will help you get thru it. From my experience its important to keep ahead of the pain especially the first few days. I personally took them quite regular for the 1st two weeks for a couple of reasons. They helped me sleep and the body heals the best at rest and also by being "lazy" I knew I wouldn't over extend myself. Granted saying that be sure to start stool softener the day before surgery. Also as many of us know insurance companies all to often don't want you overnight in hospital if they have any say in the matter. My BS made sure to let me know in an indirect way that if I wanted to stay another night I should complain of pain and ask for more meds in my IV. It is my understanding that they will not release you within so many hours of having morphine. My surgery was on a friday at 4pm, out of recovery and in my room about 930-10pm, BS came to see me Sat around 2 and asked if I was ready to go home and if not then I needed to tell nurse I was in quite of bit of pain which I did and was not released until Sunday about 1pm with no argument with insurance about my 2 night stay. This also worked out to my benefit as my husband and kids would be around sunday to help me

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2013 03:10AM cateyz2 wrote: Well ladies I am officially on the squishy side!!! Surgery went well this is what my PS told my DH while I was still in postop recovery Instuctions: no driving (??? need to call PS office today to find out for how long and if I will need a ride for follow up appointment on Monday) No lifting over 6lbs No showering until bandage/tube top removed Keep gauze bandages on til Friday/ do not remove steri strips Perscriptions for Hydrocodone and Keflex Only discomfort/pain is in the area of my sternum where he released a little more muscle to move implants closer to give me more cleavage. My final implant was allergan smooth round style 20 in 550cc. I was hoping for the style 45 for just a bit more projection but PS decides which one looks the best at time of surgery, and I know he had to clean up the BMX scar a bit.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2013 05:42PM cateyz2 wrote: Pain from the exchange is very minimal!!! only taking 1 Norco every 4-6 hours, could probably do without but I'm going to continue for the next 2-3 days as it keeps me lazy and tired and the body needs to rest to heal. Otherwise I'm sure I would be doing to much! Really bummed about not being able to drive as I wanted to do Black Friday shopping. My PS kept repeating "Its easy Peezy" in preop which made me chuckle just cause it reminds me of how a child would talk, but he is a few years older than me!

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2013 07:34AM cateyz2 wrote: Well ladies, my one word of advice to all of you when taking pain meds, be sure to take a stool softener daily to keep things moving. I have been dealing with the worst constipation in my life. I even had to reschedule my post op apt with PS from yesterday to tomorrow. After drinking 10oz of magnesium nitrate yesterday morning, things are finally starting to move although very slowly. Its my understanding this is given to people before having colonoscopy to completely clean them out and should do the trick in 1/2 hour to 5 hours. Well its now been 24 hours and Im starting to get some relief. Lets just say Ive been miserable

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 07:36PM cateyz2 wrote: I am a just a little farther out from you. I was diagnosed in April with DCIS and after discussing with my previous BS my options were (A.) Lumpectomy with 6 weeks of radiation 5x per week and tamoxin for 5 yrs or (B) Masectomy. As I did not want to go thru radiation or medication I choose to do Nipple Sparing Bilateral Mastectomy with TE Reconstruction. My surgery was 5/31 and so far everything is going well. Very small amount of tissue necrosis, but looks like it is healing up nicely. As I am out in the country I did choose a different BS( He specializes in NSM and PS closer to city.3 and 1/2 weeks post op and feeling good, still have minimum uncomfort, tightness in chest from TEs, but overall doing well. Been driving for a little over 1 wk and am not taking any pain meds except for the occasional percocet at bed for a good nights sleep. The bestnews I can say is that 0/2 of my SLN had cancer, so no other treatment necessary and I will still have follow up mams just for the VERY small chance of recurrance in the little bit of breast tissue left. Did your Dr say anything to you with regards to radiation if you have lumpectomy?? My understanding is that it is standard protocall for lumpectomy. If you have any specific questions, just ask.
Posts.Title: Nipple sparing w/immediate reconstruction? DMarie24 mags20487

Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy sched for 4/3 cateyz2 StayingFocus

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 08:20PM cateyz2 wrote: DMarie24 TE stands for temporary expander, which is placed at time of surgery and then slowly filled with saline until you have achieved size you would like to be and then 2nd surgery is to remove and replace with permanent implants. Not sure what you meant about immediate reconstruction. There are 2 types a. with TEs is considered immedite because it starts at time of masectomy, and b. where permanent implants are placed with alloderm (a type of donor skin). As far as size, search for forum "Implant sizing 101" and post your weight, ribbcage measurement and whippetmom will respond with suggested size implant. She is extremely knowledgeable. In addition once you have posted a few times also search for "picture forum" and ask nowheregirl to be added and there you can look at pictures that some of us ladies have posted during various stages. It really helps with preparing yourself for this journey we are on.
Posts.Title: Nipple sparing w/immediate reconstruction? DMarie24 mags20487
